ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the professional practice of journalism, and the art of writing. This class was full of insights that stoked my curiosity, encouraged my aspirations, and informed my career.
How to research, interview for, and write longform journalism pieces; how to ensure my process coheres with journalistic ethics.
reporting, interviewing, journalistic ethics, nonfiction writing
helped me better consider the both the ethics and methods of journalism
Its a fantastic crash course in journalism. The entire class was really supportive and the reporting projects teach you so much. Discussing the readings is also so helpful.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This course was well-organized, well-taught, and well-assessed. The assignments were instructive and fun to do. This course couldn't be improved--it was wonderful. 
The only thing I would change is that it is hard to get into, and I know many Yale students would enjoy and benefit from this course.
This course's main strength rests in the class discussions we have about the readings (which shed light on best practices in journalism) and our classmates' writings.

Strengths: Classroom dynamic is wonderful, full of people who are passionate about journalism and have interesting things to say about it. The profile assignment is such a lovely way to get to know everyone, and the reporting project is a valuable challenge (even though I found the experience of reporting for a grade to be a little weird, but maybe that is just me). Susan Dominus is the best!
Weaknesses: I would have loved a little bit more discussion of the readings during class time! I also am kind of of the opinion that the reporting project does not need to be longer than the profile -- I almost would have liked them to be equal length, and to have half of the class spent on each. I also think I would have benefitted from having to pitch and turn in sections of the reporting project a bit earlier.

a huge strength of this class is the flexible seminar/workshop format. i felt like our class got along really well and the dialogue was very generative. comments from both prof. dominus and the other students really improved my work!
Timing of the assignments was rough. Final could perhaps be a smaller endeavor
Honestly a great class all around. Readings could be lighter since we dont spend a ton of time discussing them and were working on independent pieces, but discussing them is still super helpful!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I highly recommend this class. It was instructive, fun, and helpful. I have lifelong peers, editors, and mentors.
I would certainly recommend this course to anyone hoping to improve their reporting and writing skills.

YES! I learned so much from this class, and found the experience of closely studying the craft of journalism to be such a valuable experience (and not one that's really available to you at Yale outside of this class). I thought it was a pretty perfect balance of readings, academic work, outside reporting, and classroom discussion. Take it, and take it with Sue!

i would HIGHLY recommend this to anyone interested in journalism! it gives you the really once in a lifetime opportunity to learn with a world class editor/reporter, learning tricks of the trade and details about the industry that are enriching and inspiring. this course will give you a whole different level of understanding of nonfiction and journalism moving forward, even if you only continue as a casual reader.
Yes, if youre interested in journalism at all!
